column1: #Text=[0159]Under oxidative conditions (e.g., pH>7.5), a dilute alkaline aqueous solution of dopamine surprisingly modifies substrate surfaces to include reactive, adherent polydopamine nanofilms.

#Text=Virtually all natural and synthetic substrates including, without limitation, noble metals (Au, Ag, Pt and Pd), metals with native oxide substrates (Cu, stainless steel, NiTi shape memory alloy), oxides (TiO.sub.2, NiTt, SiO.sub.2, quartz, Al.sub.2O.sub.3, and Nb.sub.2O.sub.5), semiconductors (GaAs and Si.sub.3N.sub.4), ceramics (glass and hydroxyapatite (HAp), and synthetic polymers (polystyrene (PS), polyethylene (PE), polycarbonate (PC), polyethylene terephthalate (PET), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), polyetheretherketone (PEEK), and polyurethanes (Carbothane.RTM.
#Text=(PU2))) (FIG. 1H) were effectively modified using the SMA-treatment of the present invention.
#Text=[0160]To date, over twenty-five substrates were successfully modified by a dilute, alkaline solution comprising dopamine using an aqueous one-pot process.
#Text=Potentially any substrate known to man, including various composite materials, can be used in this process.

#Text=For instance, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis showed that substrate signals such as Si2p, Ti2p, and Au4d were completely suppressed by the SMA-treated substrates as described in Example 1 (Table 1).

#Text=Instead, carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen signals were detected after the modification with a similar atomic composition of a nitrogen to carbon ratio (experimental N/C=0.09-0.13, theoretical N/C.sub.dopamine=0.125) irregardless of substrates.
#Text=Unavoidable carbon contamination in ambient conditions lowered the N/C ratio in XPS.

#Text=[0161]Table 2 illustrates the substrates and corresponding atoms (binding energy and orbital) used as characteristic substrate peaks for XPS characterization (as asterisk indicates synthetic, polymeric substrates without unique XPS signals except for carbon, nitrogen and oxygen.)

#Text=The presence of the reactive moiety (in the case of dopamine, the reactive moiety formed is an adherent polymeric film) on the substrates was confirmed by the appearance of N1s signal after SMA-treatment, as shown in FIG. 3 (399.5 eV for PS, 399.1 eV for PE, 399.7 eV for PC, 399.6 eV for PET, and 399.8 eV for PEEK).
#Text=The reactive moiety on PU-1,2 was confirmed by the nitrogen-to-carbon ratio after coating due to the presence of substrate nitrogen).
